citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the facility representative did not have access to the written Program of Veterinary Care.
A written Program of Veterinary Care is important for animal welfare because it facilitates communication between the
facility and the part-time Attending Veterinarian, it also ensures animals will receive consistent and timely diagnoses and
treatment of diseases, illnesses, and injuries.
The licensee must have a completed program of veterinary care available for review during inspections. To be corrected
by the next re-license inspection.

At the time of inspection, the facility representative did not have access to the acquisition or disposition records for me to
review.
Appropriate documentation of acquired regulated animals, and complete and accurate records of disposition are essential
for proper identification and necessary to track animals used in regulated activities to ensure their humane care, use, and
disposition.
Each exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose information concerning
each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control,
or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that exhibitor. To be corrected by the next re-
license inspection.

At the time of the inspection, the licensee did not have a documented contingency plan for the facility.
If an emergency or natural disaster were to occur at the facility, the lack of a written contingency plan could impact animal
health if the staff are not prepared to respond to the situation appropriately.
Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate contingency plan to provide for the humane handling,
treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. To be corrected by
the next re-license inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 21, 2023, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
